titlepage.titleproper: Preliminary Guide to the Gilbert Sorrentino Papers, 1950-1998

Department of Special Collections and University Archives
Stanford University Libraries

did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

did.abstract: The Gilbert Sorrentino Papers feature the materials of literary production of Sorrentino's creative career into 1999, including manuscripts, personal notebooks, and correspondence. Also present is a comprehensive collection of his papers and teaching materials from classes taught at Stanford.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access restricted until processing is completed. Please check with the department.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gilbert Sorrentino Papers. M0835. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Originally on deposit from Gilbert Sorrentino, 1985, 1990, 1993, 1996, and 1998; entire collection purchased, 1999.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Gilbert Sorrentino was born in Brooklyn, New York on April 27, 1929. His education at Brooklyn College was interrupted in 1951 by his service in the U. S. Army Medical Corps. In 1955 he returned to Brooklyn college, where he founded the magazine Neon with college friends, notably Hubert Selby Jr., Fielding Dawson, and Leroi Jones. He also served as editor for Kulchur magazine and worked at Grove Press from 1965 - 70. He published his first book of poems, The Darkness Surrounds Us in 1960, which was followed by Black and White (1964) In 1965, he released his first novel, The Sky Changes (1966), and began his teaching career with a course at Columbia University. Although highly regarded by critics, Sorrentino's work has always been experimental and avant-garde and gained popular attention late, with the publication of Mulligan Stew (1979). In 1982 he joined the faculty of Stanford University, teaching creative writing until his retirement in 1999. He is the recipient of numerous awards including Guggenheim Fellow in Fiction (1973, 1987), John Dos Passos Prize for Literature (1981), Mildred and Harold Strauss Livings of the American Academy of Arts and Letters (1982), American Academy of Arts and Letters Award for Literature (1985), and the Lannan Literary Award for Fiction (1992).

controlaccess.head: Access Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.
controlaccess.subject: American literature--20th century.

scopecontent.p: 24 Class Roll Books; Periodicals: Canto, Sequoia, Poetry, Brooklyn College Alumni review, etc.: approx. 40 volumes
Class notes, including student essays, lecture notes, etc.: 27 file folders
Photocopied reading material handouts from class
Stanford publications (The Mind's Eye, Stanford Humanities Review): approx. 20 volumes
Paperback books, some with annotations from classes taught by Sorrentino: Joyce, Blake, Kafka, O'Brien, Creeley, Beckett, etc.
Class files: approx. 20 file folders, and student manuscripts
Books of poetry and Poetry Reviews and Journals: approx. 30 volumes
Novels and poetry books: approx. 30 volumes
Poetry reviews and Journals: approx. 30 volumes
Poetry reviews and Journals: approx. 50 volumes
Poetry Reviews and Journals: approx. 35 volumes
Poetry Reviews and Journals: approx. 50 volumes
Poetry Reviews and Journals: approx. 35 volumes
Poetry Reviews and books of poetry and novels: approx. 35 volumes
